title: Fortescue faces huge native title hit
text:
“The matter of compensation is an entirely separate matter and our legal advice is consistent with our previous view that there is no material financial impact to Fortescue following today’s decision," she said.

Michael Woodley said: “Andrew Forrest says he respects Aboriginal people but in this case he is selective about who he respects." Alan Thompson

"Our mining tenure rights and current operations are also unaffected.”

YAC chief executive Michael Woodley said the traditional owners would turn their attention to preparing a compensation claim in the wake of the comprehensive court victory.

Mr Woodley blasted Mr Forrest and Fortescue over what YAC regards as attempts to divide the Yindjibarndi by supporting a breakaway group known as Wirlu-murra Yindjibarndi Aboriginal Corporation during the long-running dispute.

“Andrew Forrest says he respects Aboriginal people but in this case he is selective about who he respects and he chose to put us through the ringer,” he said.

Mr Woodley said YAC remained willing to listen if Mr Forrest and Fortescue wanted to sit down and talk about an appropriate native title agreement and settlement.

The five Federal Court judges backed a 2017 ruling by judge Steven Rares that granted exclusive native title over 2700 square kilometres to the Yindjibarndi, effectively recognising them as private owners with a spiritual connection that allowed them to decide who came onto the land.

YAC in-house counsel George Irving, one of Australia's most experienced native title lawyers, said the unanimous decision would make it difficult for Fortescue to take the matter to the High Court.

"It is unlikely that an application for leave to appeal to the High Court will be successful in my opinion at least," he said.

Mr Irving said the decision was significant in that it cleared the way for compensation payable in accordance with the WA Mining Act as well as for social disruption and that in the case of the Yindjibarndi there had been "a lot of social disruption".

Mr Woodley said the dispute and Fortescue's backing of the Wirlu-murra Yindjibarndi Aboriginal Corporation had caused heartache in the community based around the troubled town of Roebourne.

Fortescue has awarded work worth $2.3 billion to Aboriginal businesses and joint ventures since 2011, including two contracts worth $179 million to the WMYAC business arm in June.

Mr Forrest has said in the past that he opposes an uncapped compensation deal with YAC, describing it as mining welfare.

Mr Irving said the Yindjibarndi matter was very different to the landmark Timber Creek case decided in the High Court earlier this year which determined for the first time the approach to be taken in determining native title compensation claims.

He was reluctant to speculate on what size compensation claim Fortescue might face but said it would substantial.

Advertisement

"It is not as though you can take away the infrastructure that has been built on the land," he said.

"It really then comes down to what compensation is payable as a result of that infrastructure.

Mr Irving said the land involved was an archeologist and anthropologists' dream with evidence of intense use by traditional owner going back 50,000 years.

"There are archeological sites out there that are being destroyed," he said.

"That is the cultural heritage of the Yindjibarndi people, their birthright."
description: Andrew Forrest's Fortescue Metals Group faces a huge compensation claim from  traditional owners  after losing a high stakes legal battle over land tenure in the iron ore rich Pilbara region of Western Australia.
